# Introduction to Evolution ðŸ¦Ž

Welcome to **Evolution** - understanding how life changes over time!

## What you'll learn:
- **Natural Selection** - Darwin's mechanism
- **Evidence for Evolution** - Fossils, anatomy, DNA
- **Speciation** - How new species form
- **Human Evolution** - Our evolutionary history

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** All life on Earth shares a common ancestor from ~3.8 billion years ago!

## What is Evolution?

> *"Descent with modification"* - Charles Darwin

Evolution = Change in **allele frequencies** in a population over time.

## Key Terms

| Term | Definition |
|------|------------|
| Species | Group that can interbreed |
| Population | Same species, same area |
| Adaptation | Trait that improves survival |
| Fitness | Reproductive success |
| Natural selection | Differential reproduction |

## Darwin's Voyage

```
HMS Beagle (1831-1836)
```

Let's explore how life evolves!

slides.title: Natural Selection
slides.content:
# Natural Selection ðŸŒ¿

Darwin's mechanism for evolution.

## The Four Conditions

1. **Variation** - Individuals differ
2. **Inheritance** - Traits passed to offspring
3. **Overproduction** - More offspring than survive
4. **Differential survival** - Some survive better

## How It Works

```
    Population with variation
            â†“
    Environmental pressure
            â†“
    Some survive/reproduce more
            â†“
    Favorable traits increase
            â†“
    Population changes over time
```

## Example: Peppered Moths

| Before Industrial Revolution | After Pollution |
|------------------------------|----------------|
| Light moths camouflaged | Light trees darkened |
| Dark moths eaten by birds | Dark moths now hidden |
| Light moths common | Dark moths common |

## Types of Selection

### Directional
```
     Before:   After:
    âˆ§         âˆ§
   / \       /
  /   \     /
 â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’ Trait shifts
```

### Stabilizing
Middle values favored (baby birth weight)

### Disruptive
Extreme values favored (splitting)

## Important Distinctions

- Evolution is NOT goal-directed
- Individuals don't evolve - populations do
- Selection acts on phenotypes, not genotypes

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Natural selection is the ONLY mechanism that produces adaptation!

slides.title: Evidence for Evolution
slides.content:
# Evidence for Evolution ðŸ”¬

## Multiple Lines of Evidence

### 1. Fossil Record

```
Recent â†’ Living species
    â”‚
    â†“   Transitional forms
    â”‚
Ancient â†’ Extinct ancestors
```

**Examples:**
- Archaeopteryx (dinosaur-bird)
- Tiktaalik (fish-amphibian)
- Whale evolution series

### 2. Comparative Anatomy

#### Homologous Structures
Same origin, different function.

```
Human arm = Whale flipper = Bat wing = Horse leg
    â†‘ Same bones, different uses
```

#### Analogous Structures
Different origin, same function.

Bird wing â‰  Insect wing (convergent evolution)

#### Vestigial Structures
Reduced structures with no current function.
- Human appendix
- Whale pelvis bones
- Python hip bones

### 3. Embryology

| Organism | Early Embryo |
|----------|-------------|
| Fish | Pharyngeal pouches, tail |
| Human | Pharyngeal pouches, tail |

Shared embryonic features = Shared ancestry

### 4. Molecular Evidence

| Comparison | DNA Similarity |
|------------|---------------|
| Human-Chimp | 98.8% |
| Human-Mouse | 85% |
| Human-Banana | 50% |

### 5. Biogeography

- Islands have unique but related species
- Continents have similar species that split
- Marsupials in Australia

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** All evidence converges on the same evolutionary tree!

slides.title: Other Evolutionary Mechanisms
slides.content:
# Beyond Natural Selection ðŸŽ²

## Four Mechanisms of Evolution

| Mechanism | Description | Adaptive? |
|-----------|-------------|----------|
| Natural selection | Differential reproduction | Yes |
| Genetic drift | Random changes | No |
| Gene flow | Migration | No |
| Mutation | New alleles | Source of variation |

## Genetic Drift

Random changes in allele frequency, especially in small populations.

### Founder Effect

```
Large population â†’ Small group colonizes â†’ Limited genes
                         â†“
              Different allele frequencies
```

Example: Amish populations

### Bottleneck Effect

```
Large population â†’ Catastrophe â†’ Few survivors â†’ Recovery
                                      â†“
                    Reduced genetic diversity
```

Example: Cheetahs (very low diversity)

## Gene Flow

Movement of alleles between populations.

```
Population A â†â†’ Migration â†â†’ Population B
                    â†“
        Populations become similar
```

## Mutation

- Ultimate source of new alleles
- Random (not directed by need)
- Most are neutral or harmful
- Rare beneficial mutations â†’ Selection

## Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium

**No evolution occurs when:**
- Random mating
- No natural selection
- No genetic drift (large population)
- No gene flow
- No mutation

```
pÂ² + 2pq + qÂ² = 1
p + q = 1
```

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Natural selection is the only mechanism that causes adaptation!

slides.title: Speciation
slides.content:
# Speciation ðŸŒ³

How new species form.

## Biological Species Concept

> Species = Populations that can **interbreed** and produce **fertile offspring**.

## Reproductive Isolation

### Prezygotic Barriers

| Barrier | Description | Example |
|---------|-------------|--------|
| Habitat | Different locations | Land vs water snails |
| Temporal | Different times | Spring vs fall breeding |
| Behavioral | Different rituals | Bird songs |
| Mechanical | Incompatible anatomy | Different flower shapes |
| Gametic | Gametes can't fuse | Sea urchin species |

### Postzygotic Barriers

| Barrier | Description | Example |
|---------|-------------|--------|
| Hybrid inviability | Offspring die | Sheep-goat hybrid |
| Hybrid sterility | Offspring sterile | Mule (horse Ã— donkey) |
| Hybrid breakdown | F2 has problems | Some plant hybrids |

## Types of Speciation

### Allopatric (Geographic separation)

```
    Population
        â†“
    Geographic barrier (river, mountain)
        â†“
    Populations diverge
        â†“
    New species
```

### Sympatric (Same area)

- Polyploidy (extra chromosomes) - common in plants
- Habitat differentiation
- Sexual selection

### Parapatric
Adjacent populations diverge at boundaries.

## Rate of Speciation

| Model | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| Gradualism | Slow, constant change |
| Punctuated equilibrium | Rapid bursts, then stability |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Geographic isolation is the most common cause of speciation!

slides.title: Macroevolution
slides.content:
# Macroevolution ðŸŒ

Large-scale evolutionary patterns.

## Patterns of Evolution

### Convergent Evolution

Unrelated species evolve similar traits.

```
Icthyosaur (reptile)  â†  Similar
Dolphin (mammal)         body shape
Shark (fish)        â†’   streamlining
```

### Divergent Evolution

Related species evolve different traits.

```
Common ancestor â†’ Bat wing
                â†’ Human arm
                â†’ Whale flipper
```

### Adaptive Radiation

Rapid diversification from one ancestor.

```
        Ancestor
       /  |  |  \
      /   |  |   \
    Species diversity
```

Examples: Darwin's finches, Hawaiian honeycreepers

### Coevolution

Two species evolve in response to each other.

```
Flower â†’ Longer nectar tube
            â†“
Moth â†’ Longer proboscis
            â†“
Flower â†’ Even longer tube
            â†“
        Evolutionary arms race
```

## Mass Extinctions

| Extinction | When | Cause |
|------------|------|-------|
| End Ordovician | 444 mya | Ice age |
| Late Devonian | 360 mya | Unknown |
| End Permian | 252 mya | Volcanism (96% died) |
| End Triassic | 201 mya | Volcanism |
| End Cretaceous | 66 mya | Asteroid impact |
| Today? | Now | Human activity |

After mass extinctions â†’ Adaptive radiation

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Mass extinctions reset the stage for new evolutionary experiments!

slides.title: Human Evolution
slides.content:
# Human Evolution ðŸ§

## Our Place in Nature

```
Domain: Eukarya
  Kingdom: Animalia
    Phylum: Chordata
      Class: Mammalia
        Order: Primates
          Family: Hominidae (Great Apes)
            Genus: Homo
              Species: sapiens
```

## Primate Characteristics

- Forward-facing eyes (depth perception)
- Grasping hands with opposable thumbs
- Large brains relative to body size
- Social living

## Key Hominin Species

| Species | When | Features |
|---------|------|----------|
| Sahelanthropus | 7 mya | Earliest bipedal |
| Australopithecus | 4-2 mya | Bipedal, small brain |
| Homo habilis | 2.5-1.5 mya | First tools |
| Homo erectus | 1.9-0.1 mya | Fire, out of Africa |
| Homo neanderthalensis | 400-40 kya | Large brain, cold-adapted |
| Homo sapiens | 300 kya - present | Complex culture |

## Key Evolutionary Changes

### Bipedalism
- Freeing hands for tools
- Energy efficient walking
- Evolved before big brains!

### Brain Size

```
Australopithecus: ~400 cc
H. erectus: ~900 cc
Neanderthal: ~1,500 cc
H. sapiens: ~1,400 cc
```

### Tool Use

| Technology | Age | User |
|------------|-----|------|
| Stone flakes | 3.3 mya | Early hominins |
| Hand axes | 1.7 mya | H. erectus |
| Blades | 50 kya | H. sapiens |

## Out of Africa

```
Africa (origin) â†’ Middle East â†’ Asia/Europe/Australia/Americas
        â†‘
   All humans originated here
```

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Humans are not descended from chimpanzees - we share a common ancestor!
